Machine Gun Kelly’s fourth studio album offers listeners a peek into his life outside the spotlight, touching upon his troubled childhood and depression following his highly-publicized feud with Eminem. MGK described it as a concept album on Twitter, with each song functioning as a “different door to the soul.”

During an interview with Beats 1, MGK revealed he had a different album in the works for over a year, but chose to scrap it, aside from a collaboration with Lana Del Rey yet to see a release:

The original album that this was supposed to be, I erased that whole thing. I played it, and I got no reaction. I have a lot of honest people around me who were like, ‘yo, this isn’t it.’ [The Lana collab] can come out whenever and still be relevant. If anything, that one’s always there, but everything else I scrapped.

In April 2019, MGK announced the title via Instagram with a video of a woman smoking in a bathtub. He announced the release date two months later alongside a video of himself getting a tattoo of the title; he unveiled the album cover shortly after.

The album was supported by three pre-release singles: “Hollywood Whore,” “el Diablo,” and “I Think I’m OKAY.” “Glass House,” “Candy,” and “5:3666” became singles after the album’s release.

song.full_title: Sex Drive by Machine Gun Kelly
song.title: Sex Drive

description.html:
Machine Gun Kelly invites fans to “come and find” themselves by checking into Hotel Diablo over sinister production. The voice of the hotel receptionist belongs to model/actress Cara Delevingne, who co-starrs with MGK in a heist/thriller movie titled Punk.

Foster The People frontman Mark Foster was also involved in a production of “Sex Drive,” after both Clevelanders met in New Zealand. MGK envisioned the opening of his album like a movie – “I think we should just score a movie, I want it to be as if you’re driving up to Hotel Diablo.” he told.

song.lyrics:
[Intro: Machine Gun Kelly]
Come and find yourself
Come and find yourself
Don't you realize that you're the problem?
This is the reason I can't sleep at night
Hey
Why does it happen to me?
Where are you going?

Welcome to Hotel Diablo

[Outro: Machine Gun Kelly]
Come and find yourself

annotations.18612521:
This opening is ironically positive, making the listener think Hotel Diablo will describe a journey of self-discovery and confidence. However, the album is, perhaps notoriously, dark, with some key topics of the album being Baker’s highly-publicized feud with Eminem, betrayal, celebrity deaths, and absent parents. The eerie voices that interrupt these lines may represent this shift.

With this in mind, it reads as Baker inviting listeners to find comfort in knowing they’re not alone in their struggles. This idea culminates on the closing track, “I Think I’m OKAY,” on which Baker enlists YUNGBLUD and Travis Barker to create an anthem for people living with depression.

Baker shared a more positive message in this vein on 2017’s “At My Best”:

I wrote this song as a message for help
On behalf of anybody findin' their-self
I wrote this letter to numb your pain
annotations.18501475: As MGK revealed via Twitter, this voice is actress Cara Delevingne, who he starred in Punk with. He teased this cameo throughout the Hotel Diablo Tour, which took place before the album came out.

song.title: ​el Diablo

description.html:
“el Diablo” is the second single from MGK’s fourth album, Hotel Diablo, in which he mentions the people who thought his career was falling down and people which he says they “took credit and became famous” but not him.

The song noticeably changed when the album released, changing its stylization from “el diablo” and adding ​slimXX’s feature in the outro.

annotations.19707465:
MGK has always been inspired by rock and pop-punk, citing the likes of Linkin Park as influences. He fully embraced this influence on 2020’s Tickets to My Downfall, his first pop-punk record.

He included a similar sentiment on his May 2017 L.A. Leakers freestyle:

Y'all know I changed rap
Live shows I changed that
Mosh pits since way back
My guitar, I play that
annotations.18837970:
MGK described this incident in a 2017 interview with Rolling Stone:

I put my hands on a 400-pound bouncer, whose job it is to whup people’s ass like mine, and he sued me for $2 million!

RS also mentioned that MGK allegedly hit the bouncer with a bottle. It wasn’t the last time MGK was involved in an assault case — in June 2019, a man claimed Baker told his friends to attack him.
annotations.18675055:
This is one of Ronny J’s producer tags, which also appears on songs like 100k.Caash’s “FUN” and Denzel Curry’s “P.A.T.”

Ronny also produced “RAP DEVIL,” the Eminem diss that stemmed from the conflict MGK describes in the first verse:

Tell all my competition that I love ‘em
But I brought 'em back just to kill 'em again
Tell all the listeners that I said, “Fuck 'em”
If they thought I’d never be breathing again
annotations.18675018:
This line stems from a 19th-century nursery rhyme called “What Are Little Boys Made Of,” which describes feminine innocence and complacence. The rhyme receives frequent criticism for its sexist language and double-standards.

What are little girls made of? What are little girls made of? Sugar and spice and everything nice, that’s what little girls are made of.

During a performance at Sirius XM in August 2019, MGK pointed to his nose while singing “sugar spice,” suggesting that “sugar spice” could also be cocaine. He also mentioned a “good girl” having cocaine on December 2019’s “why are you here”:

I’m a demon in the night, she’s an angel with the white
annotations.18612549: MGK released his third studio album, bloom, in May 2017, and it sold over 500,000 copies in the U.S. within six months.
annotations.18612544:
Baker’s caution regarding relationships and friendships likely originates from the situation that inspired “Hollywood Whore” — he explained in an interview with Los Angeles' ALT 98.7:

I had been through something business-wise that hurt me more than… a deeper type of hurt that I never knew. Someone so close to me just did me really wrong, and I wrote this song ‘Hollywood Whore’ about it.

He also discussed this attitude on “Roulette”:

Fuck the one that turned on me, I won’t ever forget it
You learn it’s your own homies you knew since the beginning
That see you winning and then wanna see you finished
annotations.18501504:
MGK’s recklessness is a major topic on the later Hotel Diablo track “Roulette”:

How many times you gon' play with death before you 30?
But I’m chosen, so I’m rollin'
annotations.17672663:
MGK nods to his well-documented feud with Eminem, which culminated in a series of diss tracks before this song: Eminem dissed MGK on “Not Alike” and “Killshot,” while MGK dissed Eminem on “RAP DEVIL.”

MGK flaunted his “victory” against Eminem on Instagram, as well as on the later Hotel Diablo track “Floor 13”:

I just spent the winter livin' after someone tried to send a kill shot, missin' me

MGK shared in an interview with Complex that he was drunk when he wrote and recorded the first three verses of “RAP DEVIL,” so “I keep some drink in the cup” could reference his skills while inebriated.

In the music video for “el Diablo,” MGK pretends to eat a bowl of cereal while rapping these lines, which he did in the “RAP DEVIL” music video.
annotations.17326492:
Kells is saying “fuck ‘em” to the haters who doubted him, especially after his beef with Eminem where many people thought Eminem killed him with his diss song “Killshot.” MGK’s saying he’s still “alive” and didn’t die after the beef was over.

There’s also some slick wordplay — “Fuck ‘em” can be seen as “Fuck them”, but also as “Fuck Em (Eminem)”.
annotations.17285053:
Adonis (from Greek mythology), was the god of beauty and desire. The central idea of the myth is the death and resurrection of him, that’s why Adonis is also widely seen as a prime example of the archetypal “dying-and-rising god.”

Additionally, this can reffer to Adonis Creed, (Adonis Johnson), the protagonist from the Rocky spin-off and sequel, Creed. He spends the first years of his life in foster care and juvenile hall, until he is adopted by Mary Anne Creed (Apollo’s Creed widow). He lives a life of luxury and maintains a stable white collar job, only to abandon it to pursue a lifelong dream of becoming a professional boxer trained by Rocky Balboa. The character is played by Michael B. Jordan.
annotations.17285039:
I make it happen again refers to MGK’s song “Make It Happen.” The overall theme for this song is that if you can dream it, then you should work hard towards your goals and go make it happen.

MGK about “Make It Happen”:

I’d like to remembered as having walked my own path and created something new, rather than following in someone’s footsteps. I put my shoe in everybody’s footsteps along the way and realized that none of them matched mine. And said fuck it. I went and made a whole different set of footprints in a whole different path.
I trusted my struggle. It’s a long fucking journey to, not even to the top, but just to be accepted by the majority of people. Just know I laced the fuck up and got it done.

Last part of the bar is referring to the Roland TR-808 Rhythm Composer, commonly known as the “808.” It is a drum machine manufactured by the Roland Corporation between 1980 and 1983. It was one of the first drum machines to allow users to program rhythms instead of using preset patterns. The 808 was subsequently used by hip hop artists including Run-DMC, LL Cool J, and Public Enemy.

song.full_title: Hollywood Whore by Machine Gun Kelly
song.title: Hollywood Whore

description.html:
On “Hollywood Whore,” Machine Gun Kelly addresses a former business partner who betrayed him. It’s also a general commentary on his experience in the music industry and how record companies manipulate artists, much like a prostitute on Hollywood Boulevard. It was the first song he wrote for Hotel Diablo.

The intro samples Linkin Park’s “Numb” as a tribute to lead singer Chester Bennington, who died by suicide in July 2017. MGK is an avid Linkin Park fan, and he was even set to join the band on their 2017 tour, although it was cancelled after Bennington’s death. The song’s music video includes a frame that reads “R.I.P. Chester Bennington” at 2:50, and MGK also mentions Bennington on “Glass House.”

The artwork for the single depicts a devilish Baphomet puppeteer, implying that artists are controlled by malevolent forces. This imagery coincides with the overall theme of Hotel Diablo.

annotations.20903015:
Listeners can interpret a “Hollywood whore” as either a Californian prostitute or someone desperate for fame, suggesting that this person took advantage of MGK’s seeming lack of music industry knowledge to trick him.

Kells later referenced this song on September 2020’s “drunk face”:

She opened the door and walked past me
I’m a Hollywood whore, I don’t ask names
annotations.19718640: It’s a double entendre. There is so much shade due to the opague clouds and lack of sun. However, there is also shade (as in throwing shade) from the hate that he’s experienced/read in reviews.
annotations.19171017:
Death and mortality are major topics on Hotel Diablo, including MGK’s attempted suicide. In various religions, Heaven is where God’s followers, or “good” people, go after they die.

MGK contemplates whether he’ll go to Heaven on the later Hotel Diablo track “Roulette”:

I heard Heaven got a place for me there, but I don’t know if I’m goin'

It’s also worth noting the juxtaposition between the inherent goodness of Heaven and MGK’s plan to kill the subject. He paints a similar scene on “Burning Memories”:

If I die before I wake, smoke me out at Heaven’s gate
annotations.18704973:
MGK later references sleeplessness on “5:3666”:

I’m writing this at 5:3666 in the morning
Wide awake still, not even yawning
Not even sure why I’m up at dawn like I’m celebrating
When my agent told me that no one’s calling

Somebody, tell me why I’m still awake
annotations.18501726:
A common nickname for the city of Los Angeles is “City of Angels,” since the name means “the angels” in Spanish. MGK quickly contrasts this purity with “danger,” expressing his disenchantment with the Hollywood lifestyle and fame as a whole. He told Genius:

The city of angels, which is obviously a fucking joke, you know what I mean? Like it’s the city of demons, dude. The hills have eyes like everyone talks, everyone knows everyone’s business.

He includes a similar critique of the Hollywood life on the album’s closer, “I Think I’m OKAY”:

I cannot hide in hills of California
Because these hills have eyes, and I’ve got paranoia
annotations.18501671: Saks Fifth Avenue is a luxury department store chain, named after their iconic New York City location. Although it’s a symbol of high-end living, BisNow reported just months after this song’s release that the chain’s value had dropped 60% between 2014 and 2019.
annotations.17605207:
As of this song’s release, MGK’s daughter, Casie Colson Baker, was ten years old. His love for her is a big motif throughout the album — he also mentions her on “Glass House,” “Floor 13,” and “Death in My Pocket.”

MGK shared in an interview with Los Angeles' ALT 98.7:

I had been through something business-wise that hurt me more than… a deeper type of hurt that I never knew. Someone so close to me just did me really wrong, and I wrote this song ‘Hollywood Whore’ about it.

On an August 2018 Funk Flex freestyle, he mentioned a publicist turning their back on him:

Just had a publicist that left, said I was too aggressive
annotations.17240756:
Before the song’s release, MGK spoke about this lyric on an Instagram livestream:

You ever had to smile at the motherfucker you know who did you so wrong, and you love that person, and they just fucked you over in the worst way? And the people were like family? You still gotta hold it together.

He also mentions faking smiles on the next Hotel Diablo track, “Glass House”:

I always hated to smile, but it keep what is killing me hidden inside
annotations.17191753:
A “snake” is someone who’s unfaithful or traitorous. It originates from the Biblical story of the Garden of Eden, in which a snake convinces Adam and Eve to give into temptation and eat an apple, which God advised them not to do.

If a snake were slithering in tall grass, it would be hard to see, like how a traitorous acquaintance might be hard to expose.. MGK revisited this concept on March 2020’s “Bullets With Names,” which he recorded just months after Hotel Diablo came out:

I just cut the grass and showed the motherfuckin' snakes
annotations.17190204:
Machine Gun Kelly utilizes wordplay with successive numbers, a lyrical device he’s used before on his June 2013 track, “Baddest”:

Six inch heels
Five course meals
Four years she’s been my 32, my center like Shaquille
One time for my bad bitches

MGK also used a 1-5 pattern elsewhere on the same mixtape, in a song called “Home Soon”:

Now one day I’ll be too fly driving three girls in my four-door while these five Js make a fellowship of smoke rings, bitch, I’m Frodo

On September 2018’s “Rap Devil,” he played with the numbers five, six, seven, and eight:

5'8" and I’m 6'4", seven punches hold your head still
Last time you saw 8 Mile was at home on a treadmill

song.full_title: Glass House by Machine Gun Kelly (Ft. Naomi Wild)
song.title: Glass House

description.html:
“Glass House” is a collaboration between Machine Gun Kelly and Naomi Wild, mourning various dead artists and detailing problems with drug addiction and mental health.

The song leaked ahead of the album’s release, but it was not known whose vocals it contained. Many people thought that the vocals belong to Lana Del Rey, because MGK teased in October 2018 the song was recorded with her for the coming album. However, in an interview with Beats 1, MGK said that that album was deleted, and instead MGK made Hotel Diablo.

MGK said that the only one song that still exists from that erased album is this collab track with Lana, but he decided to not put it on Hotel Diablo. He continued:

That song lyrics-wise and sound-wise, that song can come out whenever and still be relevant … If anything, that one’s always there, but everything else I scrapped.

annotations.19738217:
This line may allude to suicidal thoughts, which MGK discusses in his first and third verses. He also mentions having such thoughts on the later Hotel Diablo tracks “Death in My Pocket,” which also features vocals from Naomi Wild, and “I Think I’m OKAY.”

Even though MGK references suicide and death in general throughout Hotel Diablo, he also expresses a desire to fall back in love with life, which would be impossible had he died of suicide — for example, on “Death in My Pocket,” he describes his contradicting mindset:

I’ve got death in my pocket
But I feel so alive

Aside from his career, a key reason MGK is hesitant towards acting on such thoughts is his daughter, Casie, who he references later in the song, as well as on songs like “Floor 13.” Loved ones and family are often cited as a protective factor against suicide. “Death in My Pocket” also discusses his desire to stay alive for Casie:

Hope I’m alive to see my baby get her cap and gown
annotations.19171442:
MGK’s daughter, Casie Colson Baker, was born when the rapper was only 18 years old. He also mentions her on “FLOOR 13” and “Hollywood Whore.”

MGK told Cleveland:

I added that verse months after everyone first heard the song. I think everyone thought [it was too revealing]. That was an uncomfortable moment for sure.
annotations.19170934:
“The sun” seems to refer to a better mental state — MGK touches upon depression throughout Hotel Diablo, perhaps most notably on “Death in My Pocket” and “I Think I’m OKAY.” He describes it similarly on “Hollywood Whore”:

It’s no sun, the clouds are opaque

On a more literal level, insomnia and depression commonly co-occur. MGK went on to describe sleep issues on “5:3666”:

I’m writing this at 5:3666 in the morning
Wide awake still, not even yawning
Not even sure why I’m up at dawn like I’m celebrating
annotations.19170917:
MGK also mentions faking smiles on the previous Hotel Diablo track, “Hollywood Whore”:

I still smile, but feel so fake
It’s no sun, the clouds are opaque
annotations.17531625:
MGK started smoking cigarettes to cope with stress in his life. He announced this habit on 2018’s “LATELY”:

Life’s been getting to me, I just started smoking squares (I’m stressed)
But they ain’t getting in my circle though, we still prepared (For real)
annotations.17277438:
Lil Peep was a rapper known for helping pioneer an emo revival style of hip-hop. He passed away on November 15, 2017, after an accidental drug overdose.

Peep and MGK met at a fashion show in July 2017. MGK expressed his regret about not getting to have a proper conversation at a concert:

A few months after this song’s release, MGK paid tribute to Peep with a short cover of his track “walk away as the door slams.”
annotations.17277407: Mac Miller was a rapper, songwriter, and record producer from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, who died of an apparent drug overdose in September 2018. MGK told Complex after Miller’s death that they recorded a song together, but it never came out.
annotations.17277393:
Chester Bennington was the lead singer of Linkin Park who died by suicide in July 2017. A month before Bennington’s death, MGK performed with Linkin Park in Poland, and he was set to be a special guest on the U.S. leg of their tour, which was ultimately cancelled.

Following Bennington’s death, Linkin Park held a show called Linkin Park and Friends: Celebrate Life in Honor of Chester Bennington, and MGK joined the group to perform their 2001 song “Papercut.” He also paid tribute to Bennington by sampling LP’s “Numb” on previous Hotel Diablo track “Hollywood Whore”.
annotations.17277364:
MGK’s friend Pete Davidson is a comedian, actor, and Saturday Night Live cast member who lives with borderline personality disorder and suicidal thoughts — he shared with Self:

I’ve spoken about BPD and being suicidal publicly only in the hopes that it will help bring awareness and help kids like myself who don’t want to be on this earth.

Davidson later appears on “A Message From the Count,” a playful interlude on Hotel Diablo.
annotations.17277315:
Nipsey Hussle was a rapper, entrepreneur, and community activist who was fatally shot outside his clothing store in March 2019. MGK was initially going to release “Hollywood Whore” that week, but pushed it back out of respect for Hussle.

Before Hotel Diablo came out, MGK sporadically teased fans with song snippets. He posted a clip of “Glass House” before Hussle’s death, in which this lyric was:

I’m like Stevie, I can’t see these folks

Stevie Wonder is a blind American musician known for hits like “Isn’t She Lovely.”
annotations.17277292:
Anna Nicole Smith was an American model and actress who gained popularity when Playboy named her as their 1993 “Playmate of the Year.” She died of an overdose in 2007, at the age of 39.

In 1994, a 26-year-old Smith married married billionaire J. Howard Marshall II, who was 89. The public alleged that Smith solely married him to gain part of Marshall’s fortune, and he died in 1995 without leaving her in his will. Smith took his son to court to fight for part of his fortune, but she never attained it.

MGK suggests that the women in his life simply date him for his wealth, something he also touched upon on “el Diablo”:

Fuck a bitch, though
Y'all ain’t want us before we was rich, ho
annotations.17277215:
“Glass house” can be use here as an allegory of a place where everybody can see you and judge you, but you’re trapped inside. Its literal meaning is “a place, position, or situation involving intense public scrutiny.”

But the term has other meanings as well. It’s a phrase to remind someone that they’re being hypocritical. It comes from the idiom, “Those who live in a glass house should not throw stones at others.” It means, “don’t criticize others if you have similar weaknesses yourself.”

“Glass house” can have a double meaning and be a reference to cars (as Naomi sings about ‘M3 in a driveway’). “Glass house” in ‘70s was a term for a Chevy, because these cars had alot of glass surrouindg the cabin area.

Additionally, “Glass house” could be a reference to “Castle of Glass” by Linkin Park, as the main theme of that song is experiencing the loss, and MGK has a strong connection with Linkin Park.

Lastly, Naomi Wild shared on Twitter:

annotations.17527055:
Lil Skies has been vocal about his experiences with depression, and he’s touched upon the subject on songs like February 2019’s “i.” He also spoke about it during a June 2018 livestream where he teased his song “Name in the Sand”:

I don’t know, I wasn’t comfortable enough to give [the song] to you [earlier], like, I wasn’t comfortable enough to share the real me with everybody, you know? My emotions and shit, I’m a very emotional person, feel me?

Lil Skies alarmed fans with a since-deleted December 2018 tweet, in which he said that “death [was] calling [his] name.”
annotations.17523941:
When MGK was nine years old, his mother left him and his father for another man. When this song was released, he was 29, twenty years older.

MGK previously spoke about missing his mom on “Story of the Stairs”:

Couldn’t even hit the stairs without remembering how many years I was there waiting to see your car pull up
annotations.17523938:
Around the age of nine, MGK moved to Denver, Colorado with his father, while his mother left them for another man. His father dealt with depression and unemployment following the split, straining his relationship with his son.

LSD, or “acid,” is a drug that often affects someone’s short-term memory. It’s also a powerful hallucinogenic, altering the user’s view of reality. MGK referenced this on his 2017 track “Golden God”:

I took so much acid, I be forgetting

song.title: A Message from the Count

description.html:
Machine Gun Kelly, and one of his best friends, comedian Pete Davidson teamed up in a skit “A Message from the Count.”

The interlude was originally intended to be serious, but MGK revealed it didn’t pan out that way:

[The track] was me and Pete trying to think of some elaborate interlude skit that ended up being so bad it was funnier as a shit show, so I just put that on the album instead.

body.html:
Machine Gun Kelly, and one of his best friends, comedian Pete Davidson teamed up in a skit “A Message from the Count.”

The interlude was originally intended to be serious, but MGK revealed it didn’t pan out that way:

[The track] was me and Pete trying to think of some elaborate interlude skit that ended up being so bad it was funnier as a shit show, so I just put that on the album instead.
body.plain:

song.title: Floor 13

description.html:
“Floor 13” is the seventh track of Hotel Diablo teased two days prior to album’s release.

In this song, ‘floor 13’ can be taken metaphorically for a part of Kelly’s life or mind that is too dangerous to enter. On “Floor 13,” he addresses different topics from his controversial beef with Eminem to his critics and haters. He also expresses his strong bond with his daughter and his love for his hometown, Cleveland.

annotations.19344016:
MGK takes another jab at Hollywood and the entertainment industry — he also criticizes this culture on songs like “Hollywood Whore” and “I Think I’m OKAY.” He has often called out shows like the Grammys for failing to recognize his work.

He contrasts the high-stakes Hollywood lifestyle with one he’s more used to — 216 is the telephone area code for his hometown of Cleveland, Ohio.
annotations.19256304:
MGK seemingly describes his ability to survive what life and fame throw at him, such as his feud with Eminem and the ensuing damage to his reputation.

This could also be a nod to Ini Kamoze’s 1995 track “Hot Steppa,” about Kamoze’s rap skills and musical prowess:

No, no, we don’t die
Yes, we multiply
annotations.18831884:
This agent might be the person MGK describes on “Hollywood Whore,” which is about how someone close to him betrayed him. MGK shared in an interview with Los Angeles' ALT 98.7:

I had been through something business-wise that hurt me more than… a deeper type of hurt that I never knew. Someone so close to me just did me really wrong.

He also mentions an agent on “5:3666”:

Not even sure why I’m up at dawn like I’m celebrating
When my agent told me that no one’s calling
annotations.18705374:
This couplet seems to allude to MGK’s highly-publicized 2018 feud with Eminem, and the flow even bears a resemblance to Em’s from his 2002 track “Without Me.”

MGK included a similar sentiment about his impact on the hip-hop scene on “el Diablo”:

Stop the debate if my name isn’t mentioned
In this generation as one of the greatest
From lyrics to cadence
I changed the way rappers rock out on them stages
I saw people take it, and they were more famous
So I ain’t get credit, I had to be patient
annotations.17550326:
MGK is referring to the 2014 case of Maceo Moore, a fellow Cleveland rapper better known as “Chase.”

Chase was sentenced to 17 years in federal prison for heroin distribution as part of what authorities called “the largest ever heroin bust in the region,” snagging more than 90 people on federal and state charges.
annotations.17537135: On the day of the album’s release, MGK expressed his delight regarding his daughter in the outro on his Twitter:
annotations.17530899:
Odell Beckham Jr. is a football player on MGK’s hometown team, the Cleveland Browns — his number is 13. It’s also worth noting that as a wide receiver, Beckham is on the offensive side of the team.

MGK previously mentioned Beckham on his September 2018 track “Get the Broom”:

Not at all, but the top floor, rented all
Hoes in hotels, and the hall
It’s like Odell, how I ball

“O’s” are ounces of cocaine, a drug MGK mentions throughout the record, particularly on “5:3666.”
annotations.17527255:
In late 2012, DJ Scream and Machine Gun Kelly opened for Rick Ross‘ 23-day Maybach Music Group Tour. Alongside Ross, the tour was headlined by both Wale and Meek Mill.

While unconfirmed, it’s incredibly likely this was the origin of MGK, Pusha T, and Meek Mill’s May 2013 track, “Pe$o,” appearing on his Black Flag mixtape. The mixtape was seemingly alluded to later in the song:

Like it’s Bird Box, but the blindfold is a black flag
annotations.17527026:
As of Hotel Diablo’s 2019 release, MGK was 29 years old, and held multiple RIAA certifications:
- 2012’s Lace Up – gold (500,000 units sold)
- 2017’s Bloom – gold (500,000 units sold)

MGK also made waves with hits like “Bad Things,” a 2016 collaboration with Camila Cabello that sold over 3 million copies within three years.

Also, in this verse (with the next one) MGK used wordplay with succession of numbers:

I sold 40 million records, I ain’t even 30
Give me 20 seconds, I’ll list 10 movies that I’ve been in

MGK used previously successive numbers on: “Baddest,” “Home Soon,” “Rap Devil,” and “Hollywood Whore.”
annotations.17523819: MGK is referring Hellblazer, an American horror comic book series published by DC Comics, later adapted in the 2005 film Constantine. The main character, John Constantine, is known for his wrinkly and calloused face.
annotations.17523734:
MGK is referring to Kill Bill, a movie written and directed by Quentin Tarantino. In this movie, the main character, “The Bride” (played by Uma Thurman), wears yellow-black leather jacket and pants. She awakens from a four-year coma and the child she carried in her is gone. So she swears revenge on a team of assassins—a team she was once part of—and their leader Bill.

Just like her, MGK is known to wear yellow very often.
annotations.17522898:
MGK references Netflix’s original film, Bird Box, a psychological thriller in which opening your eyes is deadly. Coincidentally, MGK starred in the film as the character Felix.

“Black Flag” is a reference to the black bandanna MGK and his fandom wears, while also making an allusion to his 2013 mixtape, Black Flag.
annotations.17522512:
MGK’s claim, here, is only somewhat true. As of this song’s release, Machine Gun Kelly, or Colson Baker, had only acted in 9 films; however, Baker is set to appear in an untitled sci-fi film directed by Ariel Schulman and Henry Joost as well as an untitled comedy directed by Judd Apatow. Additionally, Colson briefly appeared as himself in Little Mix: Glory Days – The Documentary and featured in the soundtrack for 2017’s Bright alongside X Ambassadors and Bebe Rexha on “Home.”

MGK’s Filmography as of July 5, 2019:
- Beyond the Lights (Released 14 Nov. 2014)
- Punk’s Dead (Released 11 Feb. 2016)
- Nerve (Released 27 July 2016)
- Viral (Released 29 July 2016)
- The Land (Released 4 Aug. 2016)
- Bird Box (Released 21 Dec. 2018)
- Big Time Adolescence (Released 28 Jan. 2019)
- Captive State (Released 15 Mar. 2019)
- The Dirt (Released 22 Mar. 2019)

Machine Gun Kelly made a reference to Bird Box earlier in the track:

Like it’s Bird Box but the blindfold is a black flag
annotations.17522167:
MGK and Eminem were involved in a highly-publicized feud after MGK called Em’s daughter “hot as fuck” in 2012. This conflict culminated in Em’s diss track “Killshot,” which MGK references on the chorus of this song:

I just spent the winter livin' after someone tried to send a kill shot, missin' me

MGK takes another jab at Eminem by making a play on the title of Em’s August 2018 song “Venom,” which was made for the Marvel movie of the same name.
annotations.17522080:
After MGK called Eminem’s daughter “hot as fuck” in 2012, the two engaged in a highly-publicized feud that culminated in Eminem’s diss track “Killshot.”

“Missin' me” showcases MGK’s ability to maintain his career after being dissed by one of the biggest rappers of all time. He previously responded to Eminem’s diss in a similar vein, calling it a “leg shot.” This may even spin on a line from “Killshot” in which Em claims MGK didn’t affect him:

Say you got me in a scope, but you grazed me

In an Instagram post around the time of this song’s release, Genius' social media team quoted this lyric, with a caption saying he’s unable to move on from his Eminem feud. MGK responded in a comment, pointing out how the focus on this line ignored the true nature and intent of Hotel Diablo:

this the ONE line from an entire heartfelt album that yall post ? .. and with THAT caption ? bruh [sic]

annotations.19171137:
Hotel Diablo was MGK’s first full-length project following his highly-publicized feud with Eminem. After Em dissed him throughout his Kamikaze album, MGK clapped back with “RAP DEVIL.” Following Em’s response, “Killshot,” many outlets claimed the beef would end MGK’s career.

MGK reaffirms his perseverance in his career on “FLOOR 13,” as well as addressing his attitude regarding such feuds on “el Diablo”:

I keep some drink in the cup
In case anyone got some more beef, I can eat ‘em again

Kosher foods, including meats like beef, comply with a set of guidelines established by the Jewish religion.
annotations.19171119:
Death is a key topic on Hotel Diablo, being referenced on songs like “Glass House” and “FLOOR 13.” On “Glass House,” MGK discusses his relationship with mortality:

Me and death keep tongue-kissin'

Featured artist Trippie Redd mentions playing with death on the later track “Candy”:

Play with death like I’m Billy & Mandy
annotations.18831896:
A major theme on Hotel Diablo is the pitfalls of fame and success. He describes the deceptive nature of fame and the music industry on “Hollywood Whore”:

Under the Hollywood sign, you get blinded by the glow

The City of Angels (Danger)

“Glass House” illustrates the isolating, trapping feeling that comes with success:

All alone in a glass house
Lie awake ‘til the sun’s out

The album’s closing track, “I Think I’m OKAY,” also touches upon the anxiety that comes with being a public figure:

I cannot hide in hills of California
Because these hills have eyes
And I’ve got paranoia
annotations.17569622: MGK reinstates the idea that he is both a father and a savage, and that it is not just a public image. He references “Getty” as in “Getty Images” at the end of this line. Getty Images is one of the largest online photo libraries in the world, hosting stock photos, vector art illustrations and stock photography.
annotations.17537521: MGK says he raps for the money (currency) and gives shout out to the New Orleans born rapper Curren$y AKA Spitta Andretti.
annotations.17535431:
In 2017, MGK dated American singer-songwriter Halsey, who he met while filming Roadies. The two never publicly labelled their relationship, but MGK told Rolling Stone that spending time with her made him “feel sixteen again.”

Halsey began dating rapper G-Eazy in August 2017, and that November, the two collaborated on “Him & I,” a song about a ride-or-die relationship. MGK dissed G on an August 2018 Funk Flex freestyle:

Only Eazy I fuck with is E (damn)
I seen he dyed his hair and got a hanging earring
I fucked his girl, now he look like me, this shit overbearing

Just days after hearing the freestyle, G-Eazy responded with “BAD BOY”:

‘Him & I’ is on, mad you’re listening to Halsey sing to me

MGK alleged that he slept with Halsey again on September 2018’s “RAP DEVIL,” a claim she later called “pathetic.” Since then, the two rappers have reconciled, as have MGK and Halsey.
annotations.17531686:
MGK lived in New Orleans, Louisiana (often called “the Nola”) during the time he spent filming the Motley Crüe Netflix biopic The Dirt.

Mannie Fresh is a legendary rapper and producer from New Orleans.
annotations.17529936:
River Phoenix was an actor and musician who died of drug overdose at the age of 23. Here, MGK expresses his desire to properly enjoy his life, rather than to quickly die in a piteous way.

On the earlier Hotel Diablo track “Glass House,” MGK gives shoutouts to several other musicians who died after overdosing, including rapper Mac Miller.
annotations.17527991:
MGK is reffering to Belly, a 1998 American crime drama film, directed by Hype Williams. Filmed in New York City, the movie stars rappers DMX, Nas, and Method Man. Method Man is playing Shameek, who does not hesitate to kill, but ends up dying himself.

Kill ‘em all term was popularized after Mettallica released its album in 1983.
Lastly, Kill ’Em could reffer to MGK’s beef with Eminem in 2018. He killed Eminem with “Rap Devil” song, but he suffered the consequences as well.
annotations.17526961:
“Keep your friends close and your enemies closer” is an adage that advises people to keep tabs on what their enemies are up to, so they don’t get attacked by surprise.

“Snake” is a more modern term, describing someone who is deceptive or unfaithful. MGK mentioned these kind of snakes earlier on “Hollywood Whore”:

It’s time to cut my lawn to see the snakes

A cobra is a snake with a venomous bite, recognizable by the “hood” formed when they want to intimidate a threat. MGK has even used a microphone stand with a cobra on it:
annotations.17526929: On October 31st, the world celebrates Halloween, a holiday with Celtic origins. In its earliest celebrations, people would dress in costumes to scare away evil spirits, but it’s evolved into a night where children dress in costume and go door-to-door collecting candy.
annotations.17526908:
Oscar de la Hoya, often nicknamed “Golden Boy,” is a former boxer who retired in 2009. He broke out on the boxing scene in 1992 after winning an Olympic gold medal, and went on to become one of the highest-earning boxers on pay-per-view.

In January 2020, MGK posted an Instagram story of himself with Atiana de la Hoya, Oscar’s daughter who is also Travis Barker’s stepdaughter. Barker appears on later track “I Think I’m OKAY.”
annotations.17523996: Ocean’s Eleven is a 2001 heist movie based on the 1960 film of the same name. In the movies, Danny Ocean assembles a team of eleven people and establishes a plan to rob three Las Vegas casinos simultaneously.

annotations.20273076:
Tragically, MGK’s father died on the one-year anniversary of Hotel Diablo. He announced via Twitter:

i had plans for the one year anniversary of Hotel Diablo today. that album was everything i wanted to say and i know it’s close to my fans… but my father took his last breath this morning, and ive never felt a pain this deep in my life. i’m setting my phone down. love you.

Two days earlier, the New York Times posted an interview with MGK that closes with a reflection on his relationship with his father:

He’s so stoked that I’m playing guitar now. He called me the other day and told me that he’s really starting to enjoy my music. And he’s super proud of me.
annotations.19734421:
This line bears a resemblance to the chorus of MGK’s December 2017 track “Habits,” which details his “struggles with cocaine”:

I fell in love with a very bad habit
But I feel alive for the very first time

MGK’s substance abuse is a major topic on Hotel Diablo, coming up on songs like “Glass House,” “Candy,” and “5:3666.”
annotations.18501938:
If someone has “skeletons in their closet,” they have a worrying secret or a dark past. MGK used this phrase in an interview with Disorder, while explaining how acting helps him deal with mental illness:

Acting is my new form to release all the inner demons. My team was trying to get me to see a psychiatrist. I didn’t want to; I didn’t feel comfortable letting these skeletons out of my closet. But I was in this really dark place and couldn’t figure out how to snap out of it. And I ended up getting that role on Roadies. […] That was one of the happiest points in my life, man.
annotations.17527776:
Just after graduating high school, MGK was kicked out from home by his father. He was left homeless but soon after, he got an apartment in Cleveland on East 128th with Brandon “Slim” Allen, who to this days is his close friend, but also his producer. He even mentioned living there with Slim previously in “Till I Die.” To afford pay rent and stuff he worked in many different places (including Chipotle and Bed Bath & Beyond). Often, he and Slim found themselves starving, so they would only eat chicken wings that Slim brought home from his job at Speedy’s corner store each night.

MGK became a father at a very young age. With his girlfriend at the time, Emma Cannon, he has a daughter named Casie (born 2008).

MGK with his daughter:
annotations.17357051:
When MGK was young he and his family moved all around the world and had lived everywhere from Germany to Egypt to multiple cities in the U.S.. When he was around 9 years old, MGK settled in Denver with his father, and his mother left him and his dad for other man. Due to his dad’s depression and unemployment, MGK has been bullied by the other children, and regularly fought with his father. When he attended High School, his father moved to Kuwait to work for the army and left him behind to live in his aunt Barbara’s basement. During the living with his aunt, MGK recorded his first demo tape, Stamp of Approval. When his dad came back to the U.S. they moved to Cleveland.

In July, 2017 MGK’s aunt passed away because of cancer. He wrote that night:

I lost my biggest fan and one of the biggest parts of my heart last night. I got off stage and got the worst call of my life. But I saw this picture and thought about how u were always the talk of the town in Denver cuz people would message me saying “Do u have an aunt that works at Target? Cuz I was buying a Tupac cd and she said "oh u listen to hip hop? U should listen to my nephew” and proceeded to make me buy all your albums". And when I finally made it, I pulled my tour bus up to Target and told the store to have u come outside and u started crying. That same day I also found out u had a black eye and I went to literally kill that piece of shit and u stopped me from doing something that would’ve changed my whole life. U were always my rock. I wrote my first rap in ur basement when me and my pops shared the bed and none of the kids at school understood me so I was always alone down there writing, and u were the only one who saw me for what I was going to become… the only thing is, u were supposed to see it all happen. U were supposed to come see us sell out Red Rocks and play ur favorite songs. U were supposed to come on vacation with me and Casie and see what all ur passion towards believing in what started in ur basement could amount to… but it didn’t happen. And now im cold. And drunk. And lost. And empty. And wanna make sure nobody ever makes the mistake of taking the time with the ones you LOVE for granted.

MGK wrote previously about his aunt and how she was for him like a mother in “Story Of The Stairs.” Also, he referenced his aunt and her struggles with cancer in “The return.”

All his aunt wanted all the time is MGK and his father to get along together, but they didn’t before her death. Actually it took them seven years to get them back together. The saddest thing is that unfortunately MGK’s dad has cancer, so they don’t have much time left.

In July, 2019, in the GQ UK Magazine interview, when MGK was asked ‘If you could apologise to one person, who would it be and what would you say?’ he said:

I’d say sorry to my father. I have such a rule-abiding, amazing daughter and I was such a rule-breaking, shitty son. The legal fees, the tens of thousands of dollars from the times I got arrested, the finding out your son missed a whole semester of high school because he was waking up and pretending to go but never going… I don’t know how he did it and I get why it took us 25 years to finally get along.

In August 2019, during iHeart Radio interview after MGK was asked ‘What song was the most diffcult to release?’, he mentioned „Death in My Pocket” and this particular part of it:

annotations.20846016: Big 14 is one of Trippie Redd’s nicknames
annotations.20775519: Kells is drinking shots of alcohol which affect his brain,even causing him to black out from drunkenness, but this line is also a reference to the darker idea of commiting suicide via the method of a bullet to the head. Thus, Kells links the two key themes of the song: a reliance on substances to numb his pain, and that pain itself.
annotations.17205205:
Some people, when they wake up they need a cup of coffee. Me, when I go into the studio I need to crack an Addy and open my mind up and lose all my worries from everything going on in the real world.

The studio is supposed to be for art only. I like to get a little mad and let my pen work. That’s just the way I’ve done it since I’ve done it, but yeah covering up a low with a high.
annotations.17208440:
The Grim Adventures of Billy & Mandy was a children’s TV show that aired from 2001 to 2007.
On the show, Billy & Mandy frequently played with, and make a fool of, the Grim Reaper, a personification of death.

MGK described his own closeness to death on the earlier Hotel Diablo track “Glass House”:

In this glass house, feeling like a prison
Me and death keep tongue-kissin'

He also used nearly identical wording on “Roulette”:

How many times you gon' play with death before you 30?

description.html:
5:3666 is a track on Hotel Diablo, MGK’s 4th studio album and was the first snippet to be shared from it. The track features phem. This is the first time the two artists have collaborated.

After the track was first previewed on the 2nd of April, 2019 in an album promotional video, it was also later teased by MGK’s producer and friend, Silmxx, in an Instagram story where “5:3666” can be seen on the car’s dashboard player.

The songs finds MGK unable to sleep as he battles his inner demons and problems from his addiction with cocaine to family who are taking advantage of his success. As he has done previously on songs such as “Lead You On” & “Habits,” here too, MGK personifies cocaine as a women.

annotations.19140221: It’s probably a reference to Cody Rhodes, a wrestler from WWE whose theme song was called “smoke and mirrors”. He also bleached his hair and changed his appearance.
annotations.18704801:
666 is a number associated with the devil, which continues on the sinister imagery present throughout the album. Some examples include the “A Message From the Count” interlude and “el Diablo,” on which MGK likens himself to the devil and a vampire:

I need a castle and shit, I’m on some Dracula shit
annotations.18704786:
This is a callback to MGK’s April 2017 track “Trap Paris,” which describes a wild, drug-fueled vacation.

Woke up in Paris
Broke all the mirrors (what that mean?)
Must mean, last night was too turnt
annotations.17896315:
MGK’s childhood and relationship with his parents has not gone well. The effects of this has done damage to MGK, to the point of him not even taking subjects like “family” seriously.

His mother left him and his dad for other man when he was 9 years old, he raps about it on “Story of the Stairs” and “Burning Memories.” They’ve tried to reconnect years later, but without result.

His father, who moved for over 5 years to Kuwait to work for the army, left him behind with MGK’s aunt. Additionaly, when MGK graduated high school, his father kicked him out from home.

MGK also said this about his paternal relationship in 2015, during interview with MTV:

We haven’t gotten good again. We’re working towards that. Trying. The career is a gift and a curse. He hates that I’m so honest with certain stuff, but also, he’s proud that I didn’t become a fuck-up like everyone thought I was gonna be when I didn’t wanna go to school.
annotations.17645034: MGK’s uncle selling his pictures without his permission was confirmed by phem on her instagram while she talked about the story of creation of this song:
annotations.17563139: “Glass House” is the fourth song on Hotel Diablo, which touches upon the pitfalls of fame, loneliness, celebrity death, and mental health issues. With this in mind, “5:3666” can be interpreted as a sequel of sorts, seeing MGK starting to fall victim to the dangerous habits he described on “Glass House,” such as substance abuse.
annotations.17533790:
MGK uses “her” as a reference to cocaine. “Smelling her” references to him snorting the lines he makes from the coke. Whenever “she’s” gone, he hates it, but he knows that he can get cocaine easy.

MGK has also expressed drugs as form of a girl, in his song, “Lead You On”:

Well, it’s just that, when I felt her the first time I flew
Nobody gives me the high that she do

description.html:
“I Think I’m OKAY” is an alternative rock song by rock-leaning rapper Machine Gun Kelly and alternative rock singer YUNGBLUD, featuring drumming by Travis Barker of Blink 182.

The track leaked online in its entirety on May 28, 2019 before seeing an official release on June 6, 2019, at Zane Lowe’s World Record.

body.html:
“I Think I’m OKAY” is an alternative rock song by rock-leaning rapper Machine Gun Kelly and alternative rock singer YUNGBLUD, featuring drumming by Travis Barker of Blink 182.

The track leaked online in its entirety on May 28, 2019 before seeing an official release on June 6, 2019, at Zane Lowe’s World Record.
body.plain:
“I Think I’m OKAY” is an alternative rock song by rock-leaning rapper Machine Gun Kelly and alternative rock singer YUNGBLUD, featuring drumming by Travis Barker of Blink 182.

The track leaked online in its entirety on May 28, 2019 before seeing an official release on June 6, 2019, at Zane Lowe’s World Record.

song.lyrics:
[Chorus: Machine Gun Kelly]
Watch me take a good thing and fuck it all up in one night
Catch me, I'm the one on the run away from the headlights
No sleep, up all week, wasting time with people I don't like
I think something's fucking wrong with me

[Verse 1: Machine Gun Kelly]
Drown myself in alcohol, that shit never helps at all
I might say some stupid things tonight when you pick up this call
I've been hearing silence on the other side for way too long
I can taste it on my tongue, I can tell that something's wrong, but
I guess it's just my life and I can take it if I wanna
But I cannot hide in hills of California
Because these hills have eyes, and I got paranoia
I hurt myself sometimes, is that too scary for you?

[Chorus: Machine Gun Kelly with YUNGBLUD]
Watch me take a good thing and fuck it all up in one night
Catch me, I'm the one on the run away from the headlights
No sleep, up all week, wasting time with people I don't like
I think that something's fucking wrong with me

[Verse 2: YUNGBLUD]
Roll me up and smoke me, love
And we can fly into the night
Roll me up and smoke me, love
And we can fly into the night
You take drugs (Take drugs) to let go (Let go)
And figure it all out on your own
Take drugs (Take drugs) on gravestones (Gravestones)
To figure it all out on your own

[Chorus: Machine Gun Kelly & YUNGBLUD]
Watch me take a good thing and fuck it all up in one night
Catch me, I'm the one on the run away from the headlights
No sleep, up all week, wasting time with people I don't like
I think that something's fucking wrong with me

[Outro: YUNGBLUD & Machine Gun Kelly]
Find me alone at midnight
Inside my mind, tryna get things right
(Something's fucking wrong with me)
They want to keep you calling
So you don't wake in the morning
(Something's fucking wrong with me)
Goodnight, goodnight
Goodnight, goodnight, yeah (Goodnight)
Find me alone at midnight (Goodnight)
Inside my mind, tryna get things right (Goodnight)
They want to keep you calling (Goodnight)
So you don't wake in the morning

annotations.18309609: A fun fact people may or may not know, but the end of the song is both he and I harmonizing singing good night, which was definitely My Chemical Romance’s inspired as far as their outros and intros and just song arrangement is really inspiring. I feel like there was a lot of that in our song just as fans and you know, wanting to give our generation some of that same feeling that we had. And we’d be like, what a weird concept. And it’s funny cause at the beginning of the album it’s me confronting all these problems. And then at the end of the album it’s me saying, “Hey, I think I’m okay. But you never have that period on the end of it. It’s just a dot, dot, dot. Because you think you’re okay.
annotations.18309597: Saying, “I hurt myself sometimes, is that too scary for you?” it’s like breaking the bubble that is the non-reality of Los Angeles. Or Hollywood, I should say. Not really LA. I guess Hollywood more so. But yeah, it’s more so just like walking in the middle of Beverly Hills in a robe with a fucking knife and just being like, we bleed. None of you are gods.
annotations.17277068: This song was really a lot about living in Los Angeles. You know what I mean? The city of angels, which is obviously a fucking joke, you know what I mean? Like it’s the city of demons, dude. The hills have eyes like everyone talks, everyone knows everyone’s business. Everyone is interested in all these other lives, but their own. It’s really just a reflection of living in Hollywood. Like there’s so many people interested in your life and your business and just everything travels around.
annotations.18309562: I don’t think it just means what people think it means. I think a lot of people think it just immediately means it’s suicide or I think it’s really just like I can take back my life. You know? I can make my decisions. That’s one thing I would like to clear up. Everyone thinks that means suicide. This was like saying take your destiny into your own hands, Manifest what you want and make your life yours. So misconception cleared up.
annotations.18309542: You ever really like somebody and you do something and ruin it and then they just ghost you? That’s the silence right there.
annotations.18309531: I am absolutely an infamous drunk, phone caller. For sure crossing the line. Calling who I shouldn’t be calling and saying things that are completely out of pocket.
annotations.18309518: When I was recording Hotel Diablo, I couldn’t tell you 75% of the people that came through the studio’s names. That place was like open doors for the entire city of Los Angeles. It was so dark and I was just on a four-day bender and realized, “Eww, who are these people? Why am I wasting all these time with people I don’t like?” And that’s a lyric.
annotations.18309466: The guitar riffs playing and there’s all these girls making drinks and things like that. And I freestyle this line where I’m like, “Watch me. Take a good thing and fuck it all up in one night.” And I’ll never forget all the girls looked at each other like, “Ah, fucking mood.” And that was the confirmation for me that we’re running with that as the first line. Every time I sit here, that first line play for someone that hasn’t heard the song and they’re always like, “Oh. Me last night.” Or like whatever. It’s just funny.
